textbooks: There are no required resources for this course! Students are expected to use textbooks from previous courses including lab and drug references, journal articles, and other references as appropriate.
learning_objectives: Provide care for multiple clients and their families through direct care and delegation of care to other members of the health care team.
Prioritize and carry out nursing aspects of multidisciplinary health plans that reflect legal and ethical standards of care and practice.
Assist in making assignments and supervising nursing care in the preceptorship setting.
Demonstrate using critical thinking as a basis for decision-making in clinical practice.
Evaluate leadership and management strategies in the delivery and evaluation of care provided by nurses and multidisciplinary health care providers.
Apply systems thinking appropriate to goal attainment.
Collaborate with clients, families, aggregates, and other health care providers, as appropriate to the preceptor setting, for the planning and delivery of care.
Synthesize and apply all practicum objectives evidenced by providing complete nursing care to a group of patients as it applies to the specific care area you are in.
learning_outcomes: Provide care for multiple clients and their families through direct care and delegation of care to other members of the health care team.
Prioritize and carry out nursing aspects of multidisciplinary health plans that reflect legal and ethical standards of care and practice.
Assist in making assignments and supervising nursing care in the preceptorship setting.
Demonstrate using critical thinking as a basis for decision-making in clinical practice.
Evaluate leadership and management strategies in the delivery and evaluation of care provided by nurses and multidisciplinary health care providers.
Apply systems thinking appropriate to goal attainment.
Collaborate with clients, families, aggregates, and other health care providers, as appropriate to the preceptor setting, for the planning and delivery of care.
Synthesize and apply all practicum objectives evidenced by providing complete nursing care to a group of patients as it applies to the specific care area you are in.

requirements: Satisfactory completion of a total of 120 hours of practicum hours.
No consistent marginal or dependent performance in any of the 5 evaluation areas as evaluated by preceptor and instructor.
No violation of the four CRITICAL SAFETY ELEMENTS as explained on the Clinical Time Log & Evaluation at any time during the Capstone experience.
Completion of all evaluations as assigned on Canvas.
Completion of additional assignments as noted in syllabus and on Canvas.
Submission of all required paperwork to faculty within 24-48 business hours of the last clinical day worked and no later than 2359 on Monday, Dec. 8, 2025.

instructor_information.name: Jenise Baker
instructor_information.office_hours: M, W, & F by appt; Th 1015-1315

policies.attendance_policy: Students are responsible for managing their own time and work for this course.
policies.agency_policies_scope_of_practice: Students are prohibited from conferring with preceptors and/or administrative staff at the clinical sites in an attempt to arrange their own Capstone placements, unless given explicit permission by UTSON Capstone faculty.

any_other_relevant_fields.course_description: This clinical preceptorship course will include experiences like those students are likely to experience as newly employed BSN-prepared registered nurses. The Capstone Preceptorship is a 1:1 relationship between an experienced BSN-prepared nurse preceptor and the N279P student.
any_other_relevant_fields.teaching_learning_strategies: The majority of practicum hours will be spent providing hands-on nursing care 1:1 with a preceptor in your assigned healthcare facility. All students are also required to attend a 3-day Kaplan review at the UT School of Nursing.

textbooks: There is no required textbook for this class. All required readings will be available in the Modules section of Canvas.
learning_objectives: Discuss several theories and models that explain the communication process in healthcare settings.
Identify aspects of the communication process.
Identify the differences between social and professional communication.
Compare communication patterns in various stages of health-professional interaction.
Apply principles of cultural humility to reflect patient centered communication in health care settings.
Identify communication techniques that promote effective interaction between health professionals and clients/patients.
Identify ways of facilitating communication in peer and team interactions.
Discuss aspects of organizational and group communication that differ from interpersonal communication as they occur in health care settings.
Apply the conflict resolution process.
Integrate appropriate research findings in the study of interpersonal communication in health care settings.
Demonstrate ethical and human rights principles in patient care and professional situations.
learning_outcomes: Discuss several theories and models that explain the communication process in healthcare settings.
Identify aspects of the communication process.
Identify the differences between social and professional communication.
Compare communication patterns in various stages of health-professional interaction.
Apply principles of cultural humility to reflect patient centered communication in health care settings.
Identify communication techniques that promote effective interaction between health professionals and clients/patients.
Identify ways of facilitating communication in peer and team interactions.
Discuss aspects of organizational and group communication that differ from interpersonal communication as they occur in health care settings.
Apply the conflict resolution process.
Integrate appropriate research findings in the study of interpersonal communication in health care settings.
Demonstrate ethical and human rights principles in patient care and professional situations.

grading_information.finality: All grades are final. No extra credit is offered.

topics: Serious Illness & End of Life Communication
Anger, Anxiety, and Difficult Communication Styles

assignments.name: In-Class Interview #1 with Self & Peer Reflection

policies.attendance: Attendance is required for the course. Students are allowed two missed classes without penalty; after that, 5 points will be deducted for each missed class.
policies.exams: In the event of exceptional circumstances that make it impossible for a student to be present for a scheduled exam, arrangements must be made with the professor in advance.

textbooks.title: Spanish, culture & health: An introduction for healthcare professionals

learning_objectives: Students will feel confident in brief, basic conversation in Spanish using medical- and healthcare-related expressions and terminology.
Students will be able to articulate and respond to patient concerns.
Students will be able to respond to patient's requests regarding care and comfort.
Students will be able to conduct basic interviews (assessments) in Spanish, such as the registration interview, health history, physical exam, and the more detailed situations of women's health.
Students will understand cultural and social factors that influence the practitioner-patient communication with Latino people and immigrants to the U.S.
learning_outcomes: Facilitate medical Spanish learning acquisition.
Provide learners with academic and out-of-the-classroom experiences that enhance the formative process of proficiency levels acquisition.

grading_information.clock_hours: 45 clock hours for 3 credit hours, plus time for reading and assignments.
grading_information.study_hours: Students should plan on spending 9-12 hours per week on this course.

policies.copyright: The materials used in this class are copyright protected. Unauthorized use or copying may result in disciplinary actions.
policies.sharing_of_materials: No materials may be shared online or with anyone outside of the class without explicit, written permission.
policies.generative_AI_use: No use of generative AI tools permitted. All assignments should be fully prepared by the student.

any_other_relevant_fields.course_description: Basic health care Spanish language skills and phrases related to assessment and nursing activities. This course focuses on the cultural values of Latino patients who seek health care in the United States.
any_other_relevant_fields.teaching_learning_methods: Blended format with in-class and online participation for some assignments.

textbooks.title: Medical Surgical Nursing
Kaplan Nursing
textbooks.description: A comprehensive program that will be used throughout the next two years to help prepare you for taking and passing your National Council Licensure Examination (NCLEX).

learning_objectives: Describe common human responses to health and illness in adults.
Discuss nursing actions appropriate to altered health responses.
Recognize therapeutic nursing actions in the delivery of healthcare to patients as individuals.
Propose nursing actions that promote the health of adults experiencing illness.
Summarize basic research findings that support nursing practice in the care of adults.

grading_information.passing_grade: 75 or above is required to progress in the undergraduate curriculum.

policies.attendance: Attendance at every class is critical to your success. Students are expected to attend all scheduled class sessions, arrive on time, and remain for the duration of class.
policies.late_work: All in-class work and homework must be completed by the due date to receive full credit. Missed work that is not excused will be penalized 10% per day for up to three days.
policies.missed_quizzes_exams: If you need to arrange an alternate exam date, please contact your instructor as soon as possible.

any_other_relevant_fields.course_description: Discussion of the concepts necessary to promote and support the health of adults with biological problems including related physiological and psychological responses.

textbooks: There are no required resources for this course! Students are expected to use textbooks from previous courses, research and other journal articles, and other references as needed.
learning_objectives: Synthesize knowledge gained from coursework and clinical practice to promote safe and effective patient care using clinical judgement model.
Apply national safety and quality standards to all patient care and interactions.
Provide care as a collaborative member of an interprofessional healthcare team.
Demonstrate competence in organizing, managing, and delivering safe and effective person-centered care in an adult health setting.
Evaluate common healthcare practices and compare current research findings.
Develop individual professional identity of nursing through reflection, spirit of inquiry, and self-evaluation.
learning_outcomes: Synthesize knowledge gained from coursework and clinical practice to promote safe and effective patient care using clinical judgement model.
Apply national safety and quality standards to all patient care and interactions.
Provide care as a collaborative member of an interprofessional healthcare team.
Demonstrate competence in organizing, managing, and delivering safe and effective person-centered care in an adult health setting.
Evaluate common healthcare practices and compare current research findings.
Develop individual professional identity of nursing through reflection, spirit of inquiry, and self-evaluation.

instructor_information.name: Jenise Baker
instructor_information.office_hours: Mon, Wed, Fri by appt; Thur 1015 – 1315

policies.attendance: Students are expected to attend all clinical experiences and to be on time.
policies.punctuality: Arriving late to clinical or post-conference will be reflected in the Professionalism element of the student’s evaluation.
policies.late_work: All assignments are to be submitted to the Canvas course site by midnight of the date due. A grade will be deducted 5-points for each day that an assignment is submitted past the due date, up to 3 days.
policies.make_up_work: All missed clinical hours must be made-up through alternative assignments.

medication_math_exam.requirement: Each student must pass a medication calculation test with a grade of 90%.
medication_math_exam.attempts: Students will have two chances to achieve a score of 90%.

any_other_relevant_fields.uniform_policy: Students must wear the current burnt orange uniform and adhere to specific guidelines regarding professional appearance.

textbooks.title: Population-based public health clinical manual: The Henry Street model for nurses
textbooks.access_info: Available in print and/or electronic form. Free download from UT libraries.

textbooks.title: Community/Public Health Nursing: Promoting the Health of Populations

learning_objectives: Analyze determinants of health and causes of health disparities for individuals, families, groups, communities, and populations across all levels of the social-ecological model.

Examine theory and research in behavioral and social sciences, biostatistics, epidemiology, and environmental health as they relate to health promotion, health protection, and disease or injury prevention and risk reduction.
Explain core public health functions and essential public health services.
Describe public health nursing roles and interventions applicable to health promotion, disease or injury prevention, health protection, and risk reduction.
Analyze data and policies about public health issues that can lead to public health programs.
Propose solutions to reduce health disparities using critical social theory and social justice framework.

schedule.topic: Introduction to Public Health Nursing, Core Functions of Public Health
Frameworks for Health Promotion, Community Assessment

policies.submission_format: Electronic submissions for assignments MUST be submitted in Word (not PDF or any other format) done through Canvas.
policies.attendance: Attendance will be taken randomly during online weeks and participation is required for class.

any_other_relevant_fields.clock_hours: 3 hours of class per week over 10 weeks

course_name: MONDAY PS PERINATAL NURSING CARE PRACTIC

grading_information.minimum_grade_criteria: Students must earn a 'C' (75%) or above to pass the clinical practicum course.

instructor_information.name: Heather Maltsberger
instructor_information.office_hours: Wednesdays 0930 -1130 and 1300 -1400, hybrid and by appointment

schedule.course_credit: Three semester hours based on 9 hours/week for 16 weeks

assignments.name: Report Assignments (Patient Datasheets, Care Plans, NICU Reflection)
General Assignments (Perinatal Clinical Videos Prep Outline, C-Section Nursing Care Quiz, Perinatal Loss Nursing Care, Perinatal Medication Competency)

policies.late_work_policy: Assignments turned in late will have 10 percent deducted per day past the due date beginning one minute past the due date/time. If an assignment is more than 2 days late, the grade will be 0 total points.
policies.grace_policy: Students can utilize a 1-day grace period once in the semester for submission of one assignment within 24 hours after the original due date/time without penalty.
policies.attendance_policy: Punctual attendance is mandatory on all Orientation / Skills / Simulation days in addition to hospital clinical days.

any_other_relevant_fields.prerequisites: Successful completion of all J1 courses, and concurrent enrollment in, or completion of, N244.
any_other_relevant_fields.academic_integrity: Students who violate University rules on academic misconduct are subject to the student conduct process.

textbooks.title: Population-based public health clinical manual: The Henry Street model for nurses

learning_objectives: Holistically assess the health status of a group, community or population using data, public resources, and input from community partners.
Analyze health disparities and root causes in communities and populations using the domains of social determinants of health.
Plan and apply public health nursing interventions addressing health promotion, health protection, and disease or injury prevention and risk reduction.
Evaluate changes in aggregate or public health status to determine effectiveness of interventions.
Practice public health nursing with individuals, families, groups and communities that reflects ethical, legal, and professional standards of public health nursing.

requirements: Completion of clinical hours to meet course objectives.

instructor_information.name: Nancy Guillet, DNP, MSN-PH, RN; DM
Amber Sherman, DNP, RN
instructor_information.office_hours: Wednesdays 10-11am and 1-3 pm, via Zoom by appointment

assessment_methods: Attendance & participation in Monday/Tuesday clinical activities
Attendance & participation in Thursday clinical activities

policies.sharing_of_course_materials: Prohibited without explicit, written permission of the instructor.
policies.confidentiality_of_class_recordings: Class recordings are reserved for students in this class for educational purposes and are protected under FERPA.
policies.electronic_devices: Inappropriate use of electronic devices is prohibited.
policies.uniform_policy: Professional street clothes required; specific clothing requirements will be informed by the instructor.
policies.transportation_policy: Students are not permitted to transport clients or family members of clients.

any_other_relevant_fields.course_description: This practicum requires students to apply public health nursing concepts, theories, and processes used in health promotion, disease or injury prevention, health protection, and risk reduction with individuals, families, groups, communities, and populations.

course_name: Mental Health Nursing Across the Lifespan

textbooks.title: Varcarolis' foundations of psychiatric mental health nursing: A clinical approach
textbooks.author: Halter, M. J.

textbooks.title: Manual of psychiatric nursing care planning
textbooks.author: Varcarolis, E. M.

learning_objectives: Identify the purpose, significance, and scope of the American Nurses' Association Standards of Psychiatric-Mental Health Nursing Practice.
Describe specific brain structure and function in terms of etiology and exacerbation of symptoms occurring with major psychiatric disorders.
Describe the predisposing factors, associated responses, nursing interventions, evaluation criteria and research regarding the nursing care of patients diagnosed with major mental disorders.
Describe the health promotion strategies specific to the seriously ill psychiatric population including relapse assessment and prevention strategies.
Provide evidence of knowledge of therapeutic communication/counseling strategies in interacting with patients with complex mental health problems.
Describe indications, actions and side effects of psychopharmacological interventions in the management of symptoms occurring with major psychiatric disorders.
Apply the nursing process in the care of diverse psychiatric populations.
Describe various strategies to maintain and promote personal mental health while delivering psychiatric care.
Apply developmental theory to the nursing care of the child, adolescent, adult, and elderly mentally ill.
Identify the various leadership roles and responsibilities of the baccalaureate nurse in psychiatric settings.

instructor_information.name: Veronica García Walker
instructor_information.office_hours: 5:30 PM – 8:30 PM Wednesdays, and by appointment

policies.attendance: Students are expected to attend all classes and test sessions.
policies.sharing_of_materials: No materials used in this class may be shared online or with anyone outside of the class without explicit, written permission.
policies.class_recordings: Class recordings are reserved only for students in this class for educational purposes and are protected under FERPA.

any_other_relevant_fields.suggested_resources: Other assigned readings and support documents will be posted in Canvas.

textbooks.title: Professional Nursing: Concepts and Challenges
textbooks.author: Black, B.P.

learning_objectives: Articulate the nursing role as both a scientific and caring profession.
Examine how history has changed the profession of nursing.
Investigate the current US Healthcare system and its impact on patient-centered care.
Examine nursing theories in the application of patient-centered care.
Articulate the nursing process as a framework for care.
Describe the aging process, age-related changes, and health issues impacting older adults.
Discuss selected pathophysiology, pharmacology, and patient care topics in clinical settings.
Reflect upon the importance of self-care as it relates to patient-centered care.

instructor_information.name: Carol Dwyer, DNP, APRN, FNP-BC
instructor_information.office_hours: Thursdays 0900 - 1200 OR by appointment in person/via Zoom

policies.late_policy: Assignments submitted after the due date will be subject to a 10% per day for a maximum of three days. After four days, the assignment will receive a '0' and not be graded.
policies.email_policy: Faculty will return email messages within 24 hours on business days and 48 hours on weekends. Always include N320 in the title of your email.
policies.content_warning: Some readings and other content in this course may include topics that some students may find difficult and/or traumatizing.

any_other_relevant_fields.course_description: This course examines the profession of nursing and introduces the concept of nursing process as a framework for patient-centered care. Special emphasis will be placed on topics that apply to the bio-psycho-social-spiritual needs of the aging adult.
any_other_relevant_fields.course_evaluation: Satisfactory performance on all assignments is necessary to receive a passing grade for this course.

textbooks.title: Essentials of Genetic & Genomic Nursing: Competencies, Curricular Guidelines, & Outcome Indicators

learning_objectives: Discuss the emerging role of genetic science in the healthcare delivery system
Describe the role of RNs as patient educator, advocate, and counselor in prenatal, individual, and family genetic testing
Demonstrate the ability to elicit a minimum of three generation health history and construct a pedigree
Identify clients who may benefit from specific genetic information or services based on assessment data
Analyze the ethical, legal, psychological, and social implications of scientific advances in genetics
List appropriate resources for current, accurate information relevant to genetics for clients and/or health care professionals
learning_outcomes: The integration of genetic information into nursing practice, including ethical, legal, psychological, and social issues

assignments.name: Rad Libs - DNA Conception to Death

grading_information.extra_credit: Extra credit will only be applied after students have met the requirements for passing the course.

instructor_information.office_hours: Usually M 12-1:30 & Wed 1:30-3; please schedule 2+ hours prior

policies.attendance: You are an adult - responsibility is key.
policies.late_work: Up to the professor's discretion - be proactive!
policies.student_conduct: This is a university level class and as such, you are responsible for learning the material taught in it.
policies.wellness: Your health is important! Take care of yourself and use available resources.
policies.student_honor_code: Cheating is a no-no. Academic dishonesty may lead to dismissal from the nursing program.

course_resources.name: NHGRI Talking Glossary of Genetic Terms
International Society of Nurses in Genetics

course_name: Nursing Care of Children and Their Families

textbooks.title: Wong’s Essentials of Pediatric Nursing

learning_objectives: Identify the basic legal, ethical, political, and professional standards of nursing care of children and their families.
Distinguish selected family theories and structures as they impact on children's health and development.
Describe historical and cultural variations in child-rearing practices and ways in which such variations affect delivery of nursing care to children and their families.
Distinguish the reciprocal relationship between psychosocial developmental changes and responses to actual and potential health problems.
Distinguish the reciprocal relationship between physiological developmental changes and responses to actual and potential health problems.
Explain selected health promotion concepts in the health promotion of children.
Explain selected health deviations in children and their impact on families.
Explain the use of the nursing process in ambulatory and hospital-based care of children and their families.
Select and integrate appropriate research findings in the study of children and their families.

policies.attendance: Attendance is expected at all in-person class offerings. Class attendance is not counted or graded.
policies.late_work: Any assignment submitted after the due date will not be accepted and a score of zero will be recorded.
policies.makeup_policy: No makeups for quizzes. Missed exams without prior arrangements will result in a score of zero.
policies.extra_credit: Extra credit opportunities will be made available during the course.

prerequisites: Human Development and Family Sciences 313 and 113L or Psychology 304
Credit or registration in Nursing 355P and 255D or 455

textbooks.title: Maternal Newborn Nursing
textbooks.availability: Available for FREE in both online format and for digital download at: https://openstax.org/details/books/maternal-newborn-nursing

textbooks.title: A Black Mother Dying
textbooks.author: Pie, A.M.

learning_objectives: Describe physiological and psychosocial changes for birthing persons and newborns during each phase of the childbearing process.
Discuss relevant assessment data for birthing persons, neonates, and childbearing families.
Demonstrate clinical judgment in applying nursing interventions to promote health, prevent illness, and address problems encountered before, during and after childbirth.
Identify appropriate measures that support and maintain homeostasis of the neonate.
Examine sociocultural and technological trends that affect the healthcare of birthing persons and childbearing families during the perinatal period.
Critique current research and clinical practice standards in relation to care of birthing persons and childbearing families during the perinatal period.
Demonstrate clinical decision-making pertaining to ethical and legal issues that influence nursing care of birthing persons and childbearing families.
Discuss the effect of health inequities and systemic/institutional racism within the healthcare system on vulnerable persons and their families.
learning_outcomes: Describe physiological and psychosocial changes for birthing persons and newborns during each phase of the childbearing process.
Discuss relevant assessment data for birthing persons, neonates, and childbearing families.
Demonstrate clinical judgment in applying nursing interventions to promote health, prevent illness, and address problems encountered before, during and after childbirth.
Identify appropriate measures that support and maintain homeostasis of the neonate.
Examine sociocultural and technological trends that affect the healthcare of birthing persons and childbearing families during the perinatal period.
Critique current research and clinical practice standards in relation to care of birthing persons and childbearing families during the perinatal period.
Demonstrate clinical decision-making pertaining to ethical and legal issues that influence nursing care of birthing persons and childbearing families.
Discuss the effect of health inequities and systemic/institutional racism within the healthcare system on vulnerable persons and their families.

policies.course_repeat_policy: A student must earn a grade of at least 'C' in each nursing course. A student may repeat a nursing course only one time. No more than two nursing courses may be repeated.
participation_expectations: Take ownership of learning, as observable via self-directed learning behavior.
Be active participants during clinical in-person or online and pre-post-conference times.

any_other_relevant_fields.independent_inquiry_flag: This course carries the Independent Inquiry flag.

communication.email_instructions: Please email your instructor through Canvas.

textbooks.title: Essentials of nursing research: Appraising evidence for nursing practice

learning_objectives: Explain the role of research in the development of nursing knowledge used in the health sciences.
Articulate the relationships among inquiry, theory, research, and practice.
Demonstrate an understanding of the basic components of research process.
Identify basic ethical and cultural considerations in research that involves human subjects.
Retrieve scholarly evidence from a variety of sources.
Appraise evidence to maintain a scientific basis for practice.
Discuss the effects of health disparities, systematic/systemic/institutional racism, and health inequities within health sciences research.

grading_information.grading_policy: The School of Nursing does not assign + (plus) or – (minus) to the letter grade.

topics: Introduction to nursing research & evidence-based Practice
Nursing research in the School of Nursing
assignments: Read P & B — Chapter 1, Introducing nursing research for evidence-based practice
discussion forum: PICO research question practice
Quiz: understanding nursing research, theory, and appraisal
Choosing and submit a group PICO
Due: PICO, one submission per group

topics: Coding practice and PICO Presentation Creation

textbooks.title: Physical examination & health assessment
textbooks.author: Jarvis, C.

textbooks.title: Laboratory manual for physical examination & health assessment
textbooks.author: Jarvis, C.

learning_objectives: Using clinical judgement, differentiate and provide a rationale for abnormal assessment findings.
Employ techniques to compile a nursing health history that accurately reflect the patient’s perspective of their own bio-psycho-social-spiritual state of wellness.
Demonstrate beginning level skills in health assessment using evidence-based tools and techniques.
Communicate assessment findings, both verbally and in writing, using correct medical terminology.
Demonstrate professional values of nursing and accountability behaviors consistent with the practice of professional nursing.
learning_outcomes: Differentiate and provide rationale for abnormal assessment findings.
Compile a nursing health history reflecting the patient's perspective.
Demonstrate skills in health assessment.
Communicate findings using correct terminology.
Exhibit professional values and accountability.

course_name: Nursing Care of Children and their Families- Practicum
learning_objectives: Integrate and evaluate client’s subjective and objective health data.
Assess client’s health status.
Prioritize client’s health needs.
Plan and implement nursing interventions to meet the client’s health needs in a safe, timely, efficacious manner.
Evaluate the effectiveness of nursing interventions.
Use developmentally appropriate nursing interventions for children and families.

textbooks.title: Nursing Leadership and Management for Patient Safety and Quality Care

learning_objectives: Demonstrate a working knowledge of the Texas Nurse Practice Act, Rules and Regulations, position statements, and disciplinary procedures and their implications for public safety and nursing practice.
Evaluate nursing leadership roles in settings that influence development of healthcare policy, leading change, affordability, and access to healthcare in diverse settings.
Examine the roles and responsibilities of nursing regulatory agencies and their effect on patient care quality, risk reduction, workplace safety, and disaster planning in the healthcare setting.
Employ methods of communication for collaboration in interprofessional environments to provide quality, evidence-based, patient-centered care.
Apply nursing perspectives on lifelong learning, nursing leadership, and nursing practice excellence to promote professional growth.
Demonstrate understanding of the relationship between personal health and self-renewal as it impacts the ability to deliver sustained quality care.
Analyze historic and current legislation that impacts workplace violence and the role of nursing in advocacy efforts.

assignments.name: Legal Management of Care Quiz - Kaplan
Professional Nursing Organization Discussion post and response to 2 classmates
Texas Jurisprudence Exam (or alternative assignment for non-Texas licensees)
Optional Extra Credit - End of Course Survey

policies.attendance_policy: It is expected that students attend each class period and participate in the learning activities. Excused absences include job interviews, religious holidays, illness, or extenuating circumstances due to an emergency.
policies.academic_integrity: Students who violate University rules on academic misconduct are subject to the student conduct process. Scholastic dishonesty includes cheating, plagiarism, collusion, falsifying academic records, and misrepresenting facts.

any_other_relevant_fields.pre_requisites: Nursing 325 or consent of instructor. Nursing 377 and 377H may not both be counted.

textbooks: There is no textbook for this course. All readings will be provided free of charge on Canvas.
learning_objectives: Examine the complex socio-political, multi-cultural, economic, and technological factors which have helped create contemporary health dilemmas.
Analyze the underlying premises and rationales of major comparative ethical theories.
Explore the resolution of selected ethical dilemmas through the use of models of ethical reasoning and decision making.
Analyze the interrelationship between ethics and the law and the impact of judicial decisions on health care practices and policies.
Trace the historical evolution of the concept of professional ethics in health care.
Analyze the ethical obligations and duties of health professionals which emanate from the nature of the caregiver-patient relationship.
Apply principles of ethical reasoning to the process of resolving ethical dilemmas.
Select and integrate appropriate research findings in the study of ethical issues related to health care.
learning_outcomes: At the conclusion of this course you will be able to...

grading_information.extra_credit: Extra credit will only be applied after students have met the requirements for passing the course.

assessment_methods: Assignments are always due at 11:59 PM. Assignment due dates follow a pattern as follows: The group sign up is due 1 night BEFORE the 2nd class period, Prep assignments are due 1 night BEFORE the lecture, Working day tasks are due 1 night OF the working day (Check-Ins; Peer Review), Paper components are due as follows: Draft 1 is due 1 night BEFORE the 8th class period, Draft 2 is due 2 weeks BEFORE the peer review, Final Draft is due 2 weeks AFTER the peer review, Group projects are due 2 weeks AFTER check-in 4, The movie review and letter of reference are due the last class day.

textbooks: There are no required resources for this course! Students are expected to use textbooks from previous courses, research and other journal articles, and other references as needed.
learning_objectives: Synthesize knowledge gained from coursework and clinical practice to promote safe and effective patient care using clinical judgement model.
Apply national safety and quality standards to all patient care and interactions.
Provide care as a collaborative member of an interprofessional healthcare team.
Demonstrate competence in organizing, managing, and delivering safe and effective person-centered care in an adult health setting.
Evaluate common healthcare practices and compare current research findings.
Develop individual professional identity of nursing through reflection, spirit of inquiry, and self-evaluation.

policies.attendance: Students are expected to attend all clinical experiences and to be on time. Failure to appear for scheduled clinical experiences and tardiness are viewed as unprofessional behavior.

learning_objectives: Demonstrate respect, trust, and integrity while valuing differences when working with members of other professions for the common goal of providing high-quality, patient-centered health care.

Communicate effectively with patients, families, and other health professionals by responding respectfully and seeking common understanding.
Demonstrates effective teamwork by applying principles of team dynamics, process improvement, and conflict management.

learning_objectives: Develop a plan of care with the patient or designee as the source of control and full partner.
Demonstrate effective teamwork through communication, mutual respect, and shared decision-making to achieve quality patient care.
Apply best current evidence with clinical expertise and patient/family preferences and values for delivery of optimal health care.
Apply improvement methods to design and test changes to the quality and safety of health care systems.
Demonstrate knowledge of the relationship between system effectiveness and reducing risk of harm to patients and providers.
Evaluate how information and technology are used to communicate, manage knowledge, mitigate error, and support decision-making.

learning_objectives: Apply selected nursing and non-nursing theories that relate to the nursing care of adult patients.
Recognize physiological alterations in adult patients and use this information to generate and implement plans of care.
Integrate the understanding of chronic conditions into the provision of care of adult patients experiencing acute illness.
Organize nursing care effectively to meet the needs of more than one adult patient through collaboration with other members of the health care team.
Select and implement appropriate teaching strategies based on assessment of patients learning styles, needs and unique cultural perspective.
Select and utilize nursing research findings using electronic and human resources to provide care to adult patients.
Practice nursing according to legal, ethical, and professional standards, with a mind towards advocacy for one’s patients and oneself.

Recognize physiological alterations in adult patients and use this information to generate and implement plans of care.

Demonstrate clinical judgement related to identifying critical changes in health, initiating care, and evaluating outcomes.
Demonstrate ethical and professional standards of nursing as they relate to personal and professional growth, nursing care, and functioning as an effective member of the healthcare team.

course_name: Problems in Mental Health Nursing Practicum

textbooks.title: Varcarolis' foundations of psychiatric mental health nursing: A clinical approach
textbooks.author: Halter, M. J.

textbooks.title: Manual of psychiatric nursing care planning
textbooks.author: Varcarolis, E. M.

textbooks.title: Publication manual of the American Psychological Association
textbooks.author: American Psychological Association

learning_objectives: Apply principles of effective communication to interact with patients and the interdisciplinary healthcare team in psychiatric treatment settings.
Implement ethical/legal standards for nursing practice, including professional boundaries in the nurse/patient relationship.
Apply relevant theories for interacting with patients with diagnosable mental disorders.
Collaborate with the interdisciplinary healthcare team and the patients.
Conduct a thorough psychosocial assessment to identify priority patient needs.
Conduct mental status assessments using structured tools, observation, and interviewing skills.
Integrate relevant research findings and evidence-based practice to address priority patient needs.
Incorporate knowledge of psychopharmacology into the plan of nursing care.
Apply concepts and principles of health promotion and patient teaching.
learning_outcomes: Demonstrate qualities of empathy and compassionate care.
Use a variety of communication modes appropriate for the context.
Obtain a complete and accurate history in a systematic manner.
Perform a clinically relevant, holistic health assessment.
Prioritize problems/health concerns.
Engage the individual and the team in plan development.
Implement individualized plan of care using established protocols.
Monitor the implementation of the plan of care.
Reassess the individual to evaluate health outcomes/goals.
